# Time Events
[expandable][0]
Events make it easy to change what happens over time as your program runs. Use an [blockly block][1] event to make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed. ## Do This - Add an `at 3 seconds` event block to your workspace. - Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. The sprite should begin a second behavior after some time has passed.

[expandable][0]
Events make it possible to create programs that are interactive. Use the [blockly block][1] event block to change the sprite's _size_, _position_, or _rotation_ when the user presses a key. ## Do This - Add a `when key pressed` **event** block to your workspace. - Connect a `change` block under this event. - Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run.

# Switching Behaviors
[expandable][0]
If you want to switch from one behavior to another, you need to _stop_ the old behavior and _begin_ the new behavior at the same time. You can use a new block to make sprites stop their current behaviors. [blockly block][1] You'll need to connect a behavior to this block, such as `moving east`. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens. - Add behaviors to each `stops` and `begins` block to make the sprite change from moving east to moving west at 2 seconds.

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.short_instructions: Make the sprite spin one way, then another way.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Opposite Behaviors
[expandable][0]
Some behaviors do opposite things, like `moving east`/`moving west`, `growing`/`shrinking`, or `spinning right`/`spinning left`. If a sprite has two opposite behaviors it might seem like the sprite isn't do anything at all. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens at 3 seconds. - Add an `sprite stops` block under the event. - Use this block to stop the old behavior. _The sprite should now spin one way, then another way._

Use an [blockly block][1] event to make the ship begin moving forward after 8 seconds. ## Do This - Add an `at 8 seconds` event block to your workspace. - Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. - Give the sprite a behavior to make it "blast off" (move right) across the screen after 8 seconds.

What's the bug?When you press an arrow key, the sprite begins one behavior. When you press the second arrow key, the sprite seems to stop responding.

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
[expandable][0]
The [blockly block][1] block has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. Use the `when/while key pressed` event block to repeatedly change the sprite's _size_ while the user presses a key. ## Do This - Add a `key pressed` event to your workspace. Set it to either "when" or while". - Connect a `change size by` **action** block under this event. - Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run. _Extra Challenge:_ Make the sprite get bigger when you press "up" and smaller when you press "down".

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
[expandable][0]
The [blockly block][1] has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. The `when key pressed` event block makes the sprite move with the keys, but it feels slow and clunky. ## Do This - Run the program and press the arrow keys to see how the sprite moves. - Change each `when key pressed` block to `while key pressed` to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.

This is the project you created during the last lesson. With events you can now make different things happen over time or when the user presses a key.

## Do This

-   Add events to your program.
-   Add code under each event to change your sprites, their properties, or their behaviors.

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.short_instructions: Run the code and play with the pet! When you are done, click **Finish**.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Virtual Pet

Whoa! Check out this cool pet! 

## Do This:

-   Play with the virtual pet program.
-   Read the code to see how it works. You can even make changes!
-   What happens when the pet touches the other sprites?
-   What happens when you click the pet?

Run the code and play with the pet! When you are done, click **Finish**.

This lesson contains a **mini-project**. This progression may feel very different from what has come earlier in the course for you as well as your students. These levels have some new characteristics you may want to explore before starting.

_Great job! What else can you add to your program? Try anything you like!_

Try these ideas:

-   Add another sprite that interacts with your pet in a different way.
-   Use a `when pet clicked` block to make your pet _stop_ any behaviors.
-   Experiment with different behaviors. Combine behaviors that make the sprite _move_ with behaviors like "fluttering", "jittering", and "wobbling" to make things more lifelike.

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Back and Forth!

Sometimes you might want to create a pattern of dance moves you choose. This new block lets you do just that.

[blockly block][0]

The moves you choose above will repeat in sequence forever.

-   Create an alternating routine for the lead dancer at the front!
-   Use different numbers to change the rate at which the moves alternate. Try `1` or `0.5` to alternate more quickly!

-   Change layout when a key is pressed
-   Change a property when the dancers change formation

authored_hints.courseD_bee_nested_loops_challenge2_a: Don't forget that you can `repeat` a single command or a longer pattern. You can even `repeat` a `repeat` block!

authored_hints.courseD_farmer_condLoops2_a: The best way to do this is to nest `if` statements by placing one inside of the other.

authored_hints.courseD_farmer_condLoops2_c:

-   if at corn
    -   pick corn
-   else
    -   if at lettuce
        -   pick lettuce

If there is nothing there, you won't pick anything!

authored_hints.grade3_RunningFarm_4courseD_farmer_condL:
No one knows how many heads of lettuce will grow from each sprout.

Use a `while there is lettuce` loop to keep picking until each piece has been gathered.
The `while` loop will handle empty spaces as well! Since there is no lettuce, it will not pick any and let the code move on.
You can use either a `while path ahead` loop or a `repeat` loop to go through all of the crops.

# Printing Text
[expandable][0]
To make text appear on the screen you can use the print block: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Find the `print` block in the **World** category and add it to your program. - Type a message into the right side of the block to make that text appear above your sprites. _You might print text for lots of reasons:_ - _To make characters talk._ - _To describe a scene._ - _To give instructions for a game._

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Using Text with Events
[expandable][0]
To make more text appear on the screen over time, you'll need to use events. ## Do This - Choose any block from the **Events** category and add it to your program. - Connect a new `print` block under the event. - Run your program and make the second message appear after the first. _Changing text over time makes your project more engaging:_ - _Characters can have a conversation._ - _You can tell a story._

callouts.events_category: Click here to open the Events category.

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.short_instructions: Add a prompt to the screen.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 1)
[expandable][0]
It's time to start learning how to use **prompts**. Prompts make it possible to get words and other text from the user and use them later in your program. The text the user types into the prompt is stored in a **variable**. [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Find the `prompt user` block in the **World** category and add it to your program. - In the top part of the block, type in a question you'd like to ask. - Change `???` to the label you want to use by clicking "**Rename this variable**." - Press "Run", then answer the prompt by typing something in. _Nothing else will happen yet, but that's okay!_

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.short_instructions: Use the "when answered" block to print the text from the variable after the prompt is answered.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 2)
[expandable][0]
To use the information stored in the variable, we first need to wait for the user to answer. You now have a new event block that is trigged as soon as a prompt is answered: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Drag the new `when answered` block into your program. Make sure the variable name matches the one in your prompt! - Connect a `print` block under this new event. - Make sure all the variable labels match! - Press "Run", then type something into the prompt. _Whatever message you type should be printed to the top of the screen._

callouts.answered_block: Look for a new block here!

https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.short_instructions: Combine the text stored in variables with other text.
https://studio.code.org/s/express-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 3)
[expandable][0]
Now let's get a little fancier. You can combine the text stored in variables with other text: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Look through the new blocks in the **World** category. - Use these blocks with your `print` block so that it combines other text with the text from the variable. - You might want to change the question you are asking or the label of your variable. _This level is challenging! Click the lightbulb to the left if you would like to see an example._
